command: [withheld] PowerShell spawning cscript.exe to invoke the Microsoft-signed PubPrn.vbs with atypical arguments indicative of proxy execution (details redacted for safety).
explanation: This pattern reflects Signed Script Proxy Execution by abusing PubPrn.vbs via cscript.exe from a PowerShell session. Adversaries may coerce the signed admin script into spawning an unintended child process, effectively proxying execution to bypass application control.
rationale_steps: Parent process is powershell.exe running under a standard user context.
Child process cscript.exe loads PubPrn.vbs from Printing_Admin_Scripts in System32/SysWOW64.
Command line shows unusual or non-standard arguments not typical for printer administration tasks (e.g., unexpected quotes, redirections, or network paths).
A subsequent unexpected child process (e.g., cmd.exe, powershell.exe, or rundll32.exe) spawns from cscript.exe.
Event chain: powershell.exe -> cscript.exe -> PubPrn.vbs -> anomalous process indicates proxy execution.

llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The described command perfectly aligns with T1216 (Signed Script Proxy Execution) by using PowerShell to invoke cscript.exe to execute the legitimate Microsoft-signed PubPrn.vbs script with atypical arguments to proxy execution.
